newsitem.title: USA: Maxwell ups coffee prices; producers warn of slump.
newsitem.headline: Maxwell ups coffee prices; producers warn of slump.

text.p: Maxwell House Coffee Co. Tuesday boosted the price of coffee as producers warned that a speculative bubble that has lifted prices by up to 100 percent since January might burst just as dramatically as it began.

Maxwell House, a division of Philip Morris' Kraft Foods, said it was raising the list price on its standard 13-ounce cans of regular and decaffeinated ground coffees by 30 cents due to higher prices of coffee on the world's futures markets.

The increase, which follows a similar price hike Monday by Folgers Coffee Co., the largest U.S. roaster, brings the new price for a standard can of regular ground coffee to $3.36, and decaffeinated ground Maxwell House to $4.06.
Folgers' prices are now 50 percent higher than they were before it started raising prices in February.

Meanwhile, the International Coffee Organisation said coffee futures prices, which last week soared to 20-year highs, could slump if commodity funds, which have been big buyers, start to sell the holdings that they have built up in the past few months.
"With cumulative purchases by investment funds, there is always a possibility that a massive liquidation of positions could trigger large falls in prices," the coffee group said.
Such a prospect is unlikely before the end of Brazil's winter season, which runs from June to August, when there is a risk of a damaging frost in the world's biggest coffee grower.
But the speculative character of the rally in coffee, the longest unbroken run-up in two decades, has fanned concerns.
On Tuesday, the price of the July contract closed 6 cents lower at $2.4025 a pound on New York's Coffee, Cocoa and Sugar Exchange, after rising last week to a 20-year high of $2.775.
Coffee producers are enjoying a windfall now, but fret about future volatility and a risk that, as roasters pass on the high cost of beans at the shops, consumers may switch to tea or soft drinks.
Reacting to this danger, the 14-nation Association of Coffee Producing Countries, meeting in London Tuesday, is considering making export quotas more flexible, delegates said.
They said one idea is that producers would agree to meet again if prices rose to predetermined "trigger" levels.
"There's a concern that as the market approaches $3.00 you start to impact consumption," said Steve Platt, an analyst at Dean Witter in New York.
"And producers don't want to shut off consumption."

Helping to fuel the rise in coffee prices are low inventories at the big coffee-drinking countries, which were down to 7 million bags at the end of last year or only about one-third of levels early in the 1990s.
